quote: Additional asset to add to my resume

I believe any additional knowledge and experience would be beneficial whether I was going to pursue the CPA exam or not. I hope to have an upper hand when completing job application over those who do not have a graduate degree.

I believe that the more advanced courses that you would obtain after getting the 120 hours are very beneficial to anyone obtaining their CPA license

Making each course more applicable to real world experiences, and not solely theoretical. I feel like a lot of textbooks are outdated and confined in possibilities. I appreciate project work more than exams, I believe it is more beneficial and tactical.
I am an accountant and want to explore other opportunities that require a CPA.
I am satisfied with the content provided in each class. The professors are educated and help with the classes and the process to complete my MAcc.
I think the cost is very reasonable. I compared programs and this program was one of the least expensive options.
I do not like the additional year of work experience that was added.
I want to sit for the CPA exam and j need more accounting hours and business law.
I would like to see a course added specifically for CPA preparation.

I wanted to pursue a graduate degree to obtain 150 credit hours, which is a prerequisite for enrolling in the CPA exam. Until recently, the state changed the law to 120 credit hours and 2 years of working experience. Since I am already enrolled, I decided to finish my graduate...
I would be unsure if I knew the state was going to change the credit hours from 150 to 120. However, since I am already enrolled, I will continue and finish my graduate program.

When deciding to attend graduate school, I had to weigh both the financial costs and the long-term career benefits. On the cost side, tuition was the most obvious factor. I knew that completing a master’s program would require a meaningful financial investment, especially when...
I am neutral about the change that happened. I was first upset because I had already enrolled in a graduate program, but now I see that it is better to have a masters degree and a CPA licence.
I wanted to further my knowledge and gain more experience in accounting.

With the ongoing discussions around modernizing CPA licensure, especially the move toward more technology-focused pathways, I believe the graduate program has an opportunity to adapt in ways that better prepare students for the future of the profession
Other certification requirements
Some classes do not present the information well.
The cost of 15K for the graduate degree I take as a sunk but necessary cost. This degree will allow me to avoid a lot of additional work required by the state for different certification licensures
I have never been drawn to the CPA exam or taking it. My “dream” jobs in the accounting world don’t necessarily need a CPA so to me I’m okay not taking it so the news doesn’t affect me that much.
I have compared the benefits of having my Bachelors Degree to getting my Masters Degree and having my Masters Degree would greatly impact the positions I am eligible for.

I have spoke to many people that have CPA's from where I am from. The ones that have masters are making quite a bit more because many that only have undergrads do not have CPA's. I am wanting to attend grad school to also obtain more knowledge.
An extra year of work would not give me the same level of knowledge as this year of the graduate program.
I need a career, not a job. I need to make enough money to support my family.
Broad range of unique electives that I think will give me more depth of knowledge that others who may have only worked in one industry

I didn't find a BS in Accounting to go very deep on some of the more technical aspects of accounting. I'm sure working long enough would absolutely make up for that, but I think there's a place for book learning in a field like accounting.
As I mentioned before, I am obtaining new knowledge that is helping in my career. I will be able to explore other areas of accounting, like forensic and oil and gas accounting.
Helps individuals with financial issues as well as making it more accessible.
Since work experience can be equally valued or more valued than education depending on level of experience.
Personal achievement, nobody in my family has graduated high school. Everyone has their GED.

As CPA pathways expand, ensuring that the graduate curriculum clearly differentiates itself by offering deeper technical knowledge, stronger faculty interaction, and advanced analytics or technology training will help maintain the program’s relevance and appeal.
I received a promotion while in graduate school, I believe that having a masters will make me a more competitive applicant when applying for a new position.

My personal thought is that my Bachelor's in accounting will be enough to provide immediately after college. I have kept open to the idea of grad school or a CPA, but really only if an employer pays for it.
My reasons were mentioned - CPA licensure & leveling up quickly careerwise. Becoming eligible for more roles with higher earning potential.

I think a lot more can be learned underneath a good teacher, than in a classroom. Obviously this depends on the teachers on both sides of the aisle, but anyone that has a strong passion and drive can be successful, with the right teacher.
